matches.extracted: social distancing measures introduced by governments during the 2020 pandemic reduced the mobility in the concerned cities.
matches.expected: Social distancing measures introduced by governments reduce the mobility in the concerned cities.

matches.extracted: H*: The introduction of social distancing measures is associated with a decrease in mobility
matches.expected: The introduction of social distancing measures is associated with a decrease in mobility.

matches.extracted: COVID-19 related social distancing measures and reduction in city mobility
matches.expected: COVID-19 related social distancing measures and reduction in city mobility

mismatches.extracted: The study uses mobility data from the Citymapper Mobility Index across 41 cities to assess the impact of social distancing measures on city mobility.
mismatches.expected: The effect of time and social distancing measures was estimated using a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model.

extracted: Download mobility data from Citymapper Mobility Index for March 2, 2020 to March 26, 2020.
Collect data on governmental social distancing measures for the same period from official government and media websites.
Classify cities based on the presence of social distancing measures and evaluate their effectiveness using a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model.
expected: Classify cities based on social distancing measures.
Use multilevel mixed-effects linear regression to estimate effects.

mismatches.extracted: The study found that mobility decreased on average by 3.4% per day from March 2 through March 26, 2020, and social distancing measures introduced by governments reduced the mobility by an additional 23%.
mismatches.expected: Social distancing measures decreased the mobility by an additional 23% (95%CI: 20%, 27%).

extracted.outcome_name: Mobility reduction due to social distancing

mismatches.extracted: 1. Download the mobility data from Citymapper Mobility Index from March 2, 2020 to March 26, 2020. 2. Compile governmental social distancing measures data for the same period. 3. Classify cities based on the presence of social distancing measures and assess them using a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model. 4. Evaluate the change in mobility percentage and compare it with the baseline data.
mismatches.expected: Use multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model to estimate the effect of time and governmental social distancing measures on mobility.
Coefficient of the lockdown variable, p-value, confidence interval
